newsitem.title: CANADA: Toronto stocks end higher on foreign buying.
newsitem.headline: Toronto stocks end higher on foreign buying.

text.p: Toronto stocks closed firmer on Tuesday as foreign investors snapped up Canadian issues after the ruling Liberal Party secured another majority government in Monday's federal election.
The Toronto Stock Exchange's key 300 Composite Index rose 26.64 points to close at 6432.72. Total volume was 93.3 million shares worth C$1.4 billion ($1.02 billion).

Despite winning a bare majority, foreign investors cheered the Liberal victory as a sign that the government's deficit reduction program would continue, said Maison Placements Canada trader Rolie Bradley.
"From a foreigner's perspective, it's a majority government," Bradley said. "The game plan continues."
Bradley added that stocks with the largest market value led the Canadian market higher.
Eleven of Toronto's 14 sub-sectors gained ground, led by conglomerates, consumer products, media and utilities. The three weak groups were golds, industrial products and transportation.
Advancing stocks outnumbered declines 509 to 447, while 290 issues were flat.
Among individual issues, Stelco Inc. topped Toronto's most-active list and closed steady at 10.35 on 3.4 million shares.
Algoma Steel Inc. followed in heavy trading, up 0.25 at 9.05. Investors were betting that a stronger economy will boost demand for steel by manufacturers, analysts said.
Telecommunications conglomerate BCE Inc., Canada's largest publicly traded firm, rose 0.80 to 38.00.
Nickel giant Inco Ltd. gained 0.25 to close at 44.65 after its Sudbury, Ontario, workers rejected a contract offer and walked off the job.
The production shutdown caused a brief rally in nickel prices which boosted Inco's stock, analysts said.
